p: Prevention messages should stress that T. nativa in bear and walrus meat is cold resistant and that meat should be cooked to a temperature of at least 160 Â°F. Smoking, salting, fermenting or drying meat are not reliable methods for killing the parasite ( 34). Enhanced surveillance for Trichinella in subsistence food animal populations in Alaska would help inform prevention efforts. A model programme exists in Nunavik where walrus harvested by hunters is tested before consumption ( 35). However, this requires a sustainable source of funding, a system for rapid testing and rapid communication of results back to the community.
